data.title: Roy Kelton Orbison (1936-1988)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Compare DNA and explore genealogy for Roy Orbison born 1936 Vernon, Wilbarger, Texas, United States died 1988 Hendersonville, Tennessee, United States including ancestors + descendants + 4 photos + 1 genealogist comments + DNA connections + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors Descendants

Profile last modified 2 Jun 2024 | Created 19 Jun 2015

This page has been accessed 4,027 times.

Contents

1 Biography

1.1 Professional life

1.2 Personal life

1.3 Honors

2 Sources

Biography

Roy Orbison is Notable.

Roy Orbison also known by his nickname The Big O, was an American singer-songwriter, best known for his trademark sunglasses, distinctive, powerful voice, complex compositions, and dark emotional ballads.

Professional life

Orbison grew up in Texas and began singing in a rockabilly/country and western band in high school until he was signed by Sun Records in Memphis. His greatest success came with Monument Records between 1960 and 1964, when 22 of his songs placed on the Billboard Top 40, including "Only the Lonely", "Crying", and "Oh, Pretty Woman". His career stagnated through the 1970s, but was revived by several covers of his songs and the use of "In Dreams" in David Lynch's film Blue Velvet (1986).[1]

In 1988, he joined the Traveling Wilburys supergroup with George Harrison, Bob Dylan, Tom Petty, and Jeff Lynne and also released a new solo album. He died of a heart attack in December that year, at the zenith of his resurgence. His life was marred by tragedy, including the death of his first wife and his two eldest sons in separate accidents. [1]

Orbison's vocal instrument bridged the gap between baritone and tenor, and music scholars have suggested that he had a three- or four-octave range. The combination of Orbison's powerful, impassioned voice and complex musical arrangements led many critics to refer to his music as operatic, giving him the sobriquet "the Caruso of Rock." [1]

"What separates Orbison from so many other multi-octave-spanning power singers is that he can hit the biggest notes imaginable and still sound unspeakably sad at the same time. All his vocal gymnastics were just a means to a powerful end, not a mission unto themselves. Roy Orbison didn't just sing beautifully—he sang brokenheartedly." [1]

—Stephen Thompson, NPR

Personal life

Roy, son of Orbie Orbison and Nadine Shultz, was born on 23 April 1936 in Vernon, Texas.[2][3][4][5]

In the 1940 census Roy (age 3) was the son of Aubie L Orbison in Justice Precinct 1, Wilbarger, Texas, United States.[6][7]

In the 1950 census Roy (age 13) was the son of Lesley D Bishop in Winkler, Texas, United States.[8][9]

Roy attended Wink High School, in Wink, Texas.[10]

In 1957, Roy married Claudette Frady.[11]

Roy Dewayne (1958-1968)[12][13]

Anthony King (1962-1968)[14]

Roy (age 32) married Barbara Anne Marie Wellhöner Jakobs on 25 March 1969 in Sumner, Tennessee.[15]

Roy died (age 52) on 6 December 1988, in Hendersonville, Tennessee.[5][16][17][18]

Honors

Grammys

Best Country Performance Duo Or Group (1980) with Emmylou Harris

Best Spoken Word Or Non-Musical Recording (1986) with Johnny Cash, Carl Perkins, Jerry Lee Lewis, Sam Phillips, Rick Nelson and Chips Moman

Best Country Vocal Collaboration (1988) with k.d. lang

Best Rock Performance by a Duo Or Group With Vocal (1989) as part of The Traveling Wilburys

Best Pop Vocal Performance, Male (1990)

Other Awards

Lifetime Achievement Award (1998)

Rock and Roll Hall of Fame (1987)[36]

Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame (1987)[112]

Songwriters Hall of Fame (1989)[128]

Star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame (2010)[129]

America's Pop Music Hall of Fame 2014

Vocal Group Hall of Fame as a member of The Traveling WIlburys
